Support to LAZ National Legal Aid Clinic for Women

description.narrative: NLACW arbetar för att försvara underprivilegierade kvinnor och barn genom att tillhandahålla rättslig (juridisk) hjälp. Kvinnor och barn kommer att få hjälp genom rättslig rådgivning och psykoterapi. Rådgivningen kommer att ges både av jurister och av juridiska stödhandläggare (paralegals) lokalt placerade i olika samhällen. Den rättsliga hjälpen kommer att ges inom civilrätt och familjerätt - en stor andel fall rör könsrelaterat våld. Rättshjälp kommer även att ges till kvinnor och barn som står anklagade för brott.

NLACW works to defend the rights of under-privileged women and children through the provision of free legal aid services. Women and children will be assisted with legal advice and psychosocial support services. Further, there will be accelerated service delivery through the training and establishment of community paralegal desks which provide basic legal assistance to members of the community with technical support by NLACW. This will contribute to more women and children enjoying their human rights. Legal representation will be in the areas of civil-family law matters including gender-based violence. Legal aid services will also be provided to women and children in conflict with the law.
To contribute towards creating a Zambian society where underprivileged and vulnerable women and children have fair and equal access to legal rights through legal representation

title.narrative: Support to LAZ National Legal Aid Clinic for Women
Support to LAZ National Legal Aid Clinic for Women

description.narrative: Although the 2019 reports are not due until next year, the Embassy notes that NLACW continues to deliver strong results. To site some achievements made during last year, 1,609 women and children sought various legal services against an annual target of 1,440 cases. Other achievements included continued advocacy to strengthen policy and laws to protect women and children’s rights, developing legal and human rights literature in both English and local languages, conducting community and school sensitization meetings, conducting mobile legal clinics in communities, etc. Commendably, in 2018 NLACW provided legal representation in 471 cases, where 90,4% of recorded judgements (total 135) during the period were in favor of NLACW: and overall most targets were met. Some challenges remained, particularly relating to too few lawyers, limited office space and limited funding. Especially the Livingstone office faced challenges and recorded lower delivery on set targets than other offices due to the low capacity. The Embassy has followed-up (has been a standing dialogue issue) with NLACW on the issue of low staffing and high staff turn-over, and since NLACW launched its new strategic plan, steps have been taken to increase the staffing levels in response to the End of Programme Evaluation. Through the new core support that the Embassy is providing, the Clinic has been able to scale up and recruit new staff. So far this year, NLACW have recruited the following additional staff: Livingstone Office: 2 Legal Officers (previously, Livingstone office only had 1 advocate); Part-time Counselor (previously, the Caretaker who also has qualifications in psychosocial counseling was performing counseling services); 1 additional Caretaker (previously, the Office Assistant used to also perform the functions of a caretaker whose job function inter alia involves maintaining out door surroundings, landscaping etc) Ndola Office Legal Officer 3 positions (previously, the office only had 1 position) Lusaka Office Legal Officer 2 additional positions; Receptionist 1 position; Driver 1 position Another achievement is that there have been no staff resignations since the inception of the new Strategy Plan and the WRC has put in measures towards improving staff retention. Besides the issue of staffing, a key issue that came out in the End of Programme Evaluation, and in the appraisal of the new support, was sustainability. In a response, the WRC has during 2019 engaged the LAZ Executive Committee on the need to develop a policy to deal with costs which are associated with legal aid. LAZ, in collaboration with the Ministry of Justice and other stakeholders, had drafted the National Legal Aid Policy which was subsequently adopted by Cabinet to provide a framework for the provision of legal aid services. Following the adoption of the Policy, LAZ and NLACW are now scheduled to develop guidelines for the provision of legal aid services by NLACW and these include the eligibility to claim costs. The WRC have also engaged with LAZ on the need to increase LAZ’s contribution to the NLACW and the need to provide measures aimed at encouraging lawyers to take up cases on behalf of the Clinic on pro-bono basis. As a result, LAZ is committed to developing guidelines to encourage lawyers in private practice to take up cases from NLACW on voluntary basis as part of their continuous professional developments. This is also part of the LAZ Strategic Plan which was launched in April 2019. The WRC has also since engaged LAZ to spearhead the process. Analyzing the 2018 reports, the Embassy observed that several community workshops were conducted last year. More persons were reached than during 2017, and importantly, the number of females reached increased. However, the Embassy noted that there seems to be a trend that the number of males reached decreased. For example, in 2017, 337 males were reached through workshops on GBV: in 2018 the number reduced to 260 – 380 males were reached through workshops on women and child rights in 2017: in 2018 nr. reached was 232. High participation from both genders will be important in attaining the desired results in the communities. Engaging men is particularly key for addressing patriarchy and addressing social norms. Through dialogue with the Embassy, the NLACW have committed to ensuring that both women and men participate and for some of the activities, more men and boys will be engaged for transformative change during the new Strategy Plan.
